name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I often say that oversight is how we close the gap between what the law says and what's happening. Title VII requires an annual report to Congress on the demographic data of those who couldn't clear a background check, so we can better understand how our laws are working. (10/10)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
Existing law also allows Americans to equip semi-automatic rifles with high capacity magazines, which are designed to shoot and kill en masse. Title VI bans all but few from importing, manufacturing, selling, transferring, or owning such magazines. (9/10)
https://t.co/3ltPgx9zPU

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Americans can't legally own fully automatic rifles and machine guns made after 1986, but up until recently, you could buy a "bump stock” to dramatically increase the rate of fire on a semi-automatic rifle. Title V tightens an existing—but flimsy—ban on these devices. (8/10)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Gun violence is the leading cause of death for American children. Too often, kids find and use guns that weren't properly stored in their home or in the home of a friend or relative. Title IV includes several provisions to help families store their firearms more safely. (7/10)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Ghost guns, meaning guns that lack serial numbers and can't be traced, aren't subject to existing law because they don't fit the legal definition of "firearm." Title III amends the law so these guns, including those made from kits and via a 3D printer, are regulated. (6/10)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Another example: it's illegal to buy guns for someone who can't pass a background check, but few are ever prosecuted under federal law. There's also no federal statute that prohibits gun trafficking. Title II cracks down on these serious crimes by increasing penalties. (5/10)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Our gun laws are littered with loopholes. For example, Americans need to be 21 to buy a handgun—but they can legally purchase certain semi-automatic rifles and shotguns at 18. Title I of the Protecting Our Kids Act raises the purchasing age to 21 for these weapons. (4/10)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: TL;DR: I voted YES on all 7 proposals to reduce gun violence and keep the American people safe. Too many communities, including ours in Orange County, know the pain of gun violence. (3/10)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: The House voted on the Protecting Our Kids Act today. This legislation is composed of 7 "titles"—i.e. different sections that seek to tackle various facets of the gun violence epidemic. Each title was voted on separately to boost accountability and transparency. (2/10)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
110+ people die in the U.S. *every day* from gun violence. I urged House leadership to hold separate votes on common sense gun safety measures so Americans would know exactly where their Representative stands—with them or with the gun lobby.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Lives are on the line. Congress needs to hold Big Pharma accountable by passing the #BuildBackBetter Act, which allows Medicare to negotiate drug prices, caps out-of-pocket costs for seniors, and recovers taxpayer dollars when companies jack up prices faster than inflation. (8/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
We now have more evidence that research and development needs do not justify high drug prices. All of the drugs studied are priced significantly higher today than they were at launch.

In May, I confronted a Big Pharma CEO about this R&D myth 👇 (7/8)

https://t.co/c9NUVG1iak

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
Big Pharma doesn’t just weaponize patient assistance programs to squash competition. See our office's report on how pharmaceutical giants gobble up small companies that would otherwise make them compete—and reduce their prices ⤵️ (6/8)

https://t.co/DnuZtLrOWb

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Here’s the kicker: Big Pharma spends far less on these programs compared to total revenue. They provide support long enough for patients to start depending on a drug, but not long enough to be a sustainable solution—then they write off these donations to cheat the tax code. (5/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I'm laser-focused on the findings that show drug companies use patient assistance programs as public relations tools to undercut competition. Big Pharma hooks Americans on drugs right as their exclusivity is ending, so patients won’t seek out more affordable treatments. (4/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
Internal documents show that Big Pharma is specifically targeting the U.S. market because Medicare can’t negotiate. Taxpayers lost more than $25 billion over a 5 year period because of this policy.

It's fiscally irresponsible not to let Medicare negotiate drug prices. (3/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Price gouging hurts both patients and taxpayers. The report found that Big Pharma jacked up the prices of 12 drugs 250x over the past several years. Taxpayers are footing that multi-billion-dollar bill through Medicare, which can’t even negotiate how much it has to pay. (2/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Yesterday, @OversightDems published its final staff report into Big Pharma's price gouging. The findings are egregious—but they’re not surprising. Drug manufacturers have long prioritized their profits over the physical and financial health of families. (THREAD ⬇️)

tweet_text: Border cities, state agencies, and charities step up where the U.S. government fails. The CA Office of Emergency Services shoulders the cost and work of getting migrants tested and vaccinated for COVID and Jewish Family Services provides a compassionate welcome. (16/x) https://t.co/yCtSdGwvP4

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Border agents have to deport most migrants without any consideration and apply a vague humanitarian parole standard that's almost impossible to meet. Seriously ill migrants may be admitted to the U.S. to get urgent medical care, for example, only to be deported days later. (15/x)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Border patrol told me heartbreaking stories about migrants losing their lives and how their law enforcement work becomes difficult search and rescue missions. They described dangers of floods and toxic waste in the Tijuana River Channel that endanger migrants and agents. (14/x) https://t.co/y4mlkLhWvO

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: By eliminating any way to even apply for asylum, the U.S. government is enabling human traffickers to control the process or leaving the strong and fit to their own efforts. Left behind are women, children, elderly, and people with disabilities. (13/x)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: We are violating laws that require us to review migrants for a legitimate fear of persecution in their home countries. Asylum is a legal process. It should be a transparent and fair system. In its place are smugglers and injustice. (12/x)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: She had family to welcome her to the U.S. as did all the other migrants that I spoke with. Wearing masks and waiting their turn, everyone had one question: how do I apply for asylum with the U.S. government? I was a member of Congress, and the answer was grim. (11/x) https://t.co/djmXaR52uP

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: One woman came to TX from Ecuador. She was held in detention for days, flown overnight to CA for “processing,” then deposited at the shelter. I held her exhausted daughter, as she told me crying about fleeing an abusive husband. (Thanks @AlOtroLado_Org for translating). (10/x) https://t.co/w2Rdm2HrRK

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I visited Embajadores de Jesús in Tijuana, run by a compassionate pastor who tries to shelter everyone. I saw hundreds of people who have no home and no next step, peacefully and patiently sharing one room. No privacy. No personal belongings. (9/x) https://t.co/KDv8Mtx0zD

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I visited Tijuana and saw the circumstances facing migrants. In the Chaparral camp, gangs control migrants’ lives, often extorting or victimizing them. The violence makes it unsafe for advocates to visit, and I viewed at a distance. (8/x) https://t.co/Hm0AZVlg9u

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: The response was silence. Here is the truth: There is no process. A person fleeing violence cannot go to our border and apply for asylum. If you walk up to the border without a visa or U.S. residence, you are ignored. How can migrants get in line if there is no line? (7/x)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: A common point raised about our immigration policy is that those seeking to build a life in the U.S. should “wait in line.” So I asked U.S. Customs and Border Patrol to show me the line. Where would a refugee go? How does screening occur? How long is the wait? (6/x) https://t.co/oGCi4QtT9b

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: However, secure borders are not sealed borders. A regular and orderly process for entry—for everything from goods to asylees—is required by U.S. and international laws. One-third of the people I represent are foreign born, and they are neighbors and co-workers. (5/x)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Border patrol told me that our border is the most secure in its history. Federal data show that the top country of origin for new immigrants is China. Visa overstays now outnumber unlawful border crossings as the main source of unauthorized immigration to the U.S. (4/x)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: At the busiest port of entry, San Ysidro, I saw new screening technology, including biometric and vehicle scanning tools. I crossed into the U.S., seeing for myself how agents use technology, experience, and training to identify unlawful activity. (I was admitted!) (3/x) https://t.co/QwssUVfvX7

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Borders are a necessary part of defining a nation-state. Each country sets border policy on the people and goods that enter and exit, and does so in the context of its neighbors, global affairs, and values. That policy should be lawful and fair. (2/x)

name: Rep. Katie Porter

tweet_text: We all have an interest in our economy’s future. That means we all have an interest in child care. Right now, Congressional committees are working on child care policy. @RepSherrill and I led 100+ of our colleagues in laying out what an effective child care investment needs.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: The child care crisis is a crisis of productivity. It's economic quicksand that's miring multiple generations: older folks who provide unpaid child care to grandchildren, parents who exit the workforce, and kids who fall behind because their families can't afford quality care.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: These realities are a big problem for our economy. Businesses can't recruit because child care eats up nearly all entry-level pay. Women are stalled out in parity in achieving leadership positions. Jobs during non-traditional hours are dominated by men.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
Facts:
1⃣ In most states, child care costs more than in-state college tuition.
2⃣ Child care costs have risen 1000% in recent years—faster than housing and health care.
3⃣ Women got 12% of new jobs last month. At this rate, it’ll take 9 years to return to pre-pandemic employment.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: If you want a strong and growing economy, you should care about child care. Millions are leaving the workforce, hesitating to form small businesses, or forgoing promotions because child care is unaffordable for most families. Our entire economy is hurt as a result. (THREAD)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I came to Congress to do the work and get families help. But House Republicans use Motions to Recommit as procedural maneuvers to stop progress on critical legislation instead of trying to improve policy. Don’t take my word for it; look at their own memo: https://t.co/nLilqAHRqn

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: However, in my last term, House Republicans offered Motions to Recommit in bad faith, to force “gotcha” votes. This year, House rules were changed so that MTRs send bills back to the committees they originate from—delaying votes or killing bills entirely.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: The minority party can offer a Motion to Recommit just before we vote on final passage of a bill. If the MTR is adopted, the text of the bill is revised. Historically, MTRs were offered by Members “friendly” to the bill, as a way to correct errors in the text.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: When I ran for Congress, I made a promise to be transparent about the major decisions I make as Representative for California’s 45th District. So, I’d like to explain “Motions to Recommit” (MTRs) and my recent decision to uniformly vote NO on all of them. [THREAD]

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: We just wrapped up our @OversightDems meeting considering COVID disaster relief legislation. Want the inside look? Check out my 🧵🧵on today’s mark-up. https://t.co/ODYatbei5p https://t.co/H6N5mduijN

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
34/34 After 9 hours, the mark-up is finally over! 🙏

We approved our parts of the COVID relief bill by a vote of 23-18 (other committees are in charge of looking at other aspects of COVID relief). Next: votes by the full House.

Thank you to everyone who followed along.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 33/x I did speak up earlier in this meeting to emphasize how desperately and urgently families need help. Watch 👇👇 https://t.co/sUGh1YDzJk

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 32/x We have now passed 8 hours in this mark up, and I have a little bit of a confession... This is probably the fewest average words per hour that I have ever uttered. It’s been nothing but “yes” or “no,” and we all know that is just not like me.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 31/x Rep. Comer, who is the Ranking Member of the Committee (highest ranking Republican), is talking about the World Health Organization and how it is responsible for COVID. Attacking international public health efforts is not how to solve a global pandemic.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
My message during today's @OversightDems meeting:

Americans need help. It doesn’t matter if they’re conservative or liberal. It doesn’t matter if they live in a big city, a suburb, or a small rural town. They are all struggling—and will continue to struggle—unless we act now. https://t.co/Bdpz6du12N

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 30/x One bright side of a long and “robust” mark-up: hearing from new voices, like Byron Donalds and Yvette Harrell. Junior members question last and rarely address the full House, so a mark-up is a real chance to hear their perspectives. I may not agree, but I’m listening. 👂

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 29/x Rep. Comer just lauded his “colleague from Florida who ran to fight for taxpayers of Florida.” He was referring to Rep. Nancy Mace, who represents South Carolina. It's been a long day for everyone. 😬

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 28/x Rep. Nancy Mace (R-SC) used her time to talk about how she serves on 3 committees in Congress and that she has noticed that Democrats and Republicans are not voting together.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 27/x As is sadly typical, the mark-up has devolved into both sides grumbling that this mark-up is taking too long—and blaming each other for that.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 26/x Admittedly, a couple amendments (of the 40!) were on topic. For example, we debated whether smaller cities should receive funds directly from the U.S. Treasury via a not yet established system, or should receive funds via distributions to each state, as prior bills did.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 25/x So far, we have had amendments filed on a range of favorite hot button Republican issues: Keystone XL, Paris Climate Accord, mail-in ballots, abortion, fracking, immigration, census data, etc. None of these are relevant to state and local government funding or the pandemic.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 24/x We are nearing the 7th hour of this mark-up. Still, many of the amendments being offered are unrelated to the main point of the legislation: funding for state and local governments.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: @OtterFi You can find a list of members here: https://t.co/yeFiCy7ZFF

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 23/x Chairs particularly need a lot of stamina to run a hearing—they must remain in place and preside, or else ask someone to chair temporarily. I’ve never gotten to do it but think it looks like fun. Probably less fun remotely when the actual gavel stays in the hearing room...

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 22/x We are taking a 5 minute recess. This is recess in the same sense as in school. It’s a chance to take a break.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
21/x I carry 3 cell phones and an iPad and try to have at least two of the devices fully charged at the start of the morning for exactly this reason.

I challenge tech innovators to make a battery that can hold up to the partisanship of Congress!

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 20/x As this mark-up goes on, everybody on a device is plugging in. I started fully charged, plugged in a few hours ago, but video takes so much battery that I’m down to 3%!

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 19/x “En bloc” is when we vote on several amendments together as a package. It's most common when amendments are similar in nature or less controversial. For example, this morning, several amendments tried to limit how states and localities could spend the proposed COVID relief.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 18/x Republicans have requested recorded votes for all their amendments from the 3 hours of mark-up so far. Committee rules say we can roll these to a fixed time. Several amendments were taken together “en bloc.” What is “en bloc?”

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 17/x Any member can then request a recorded vote. What is a “recorded vote?” It's where the clerk of the Committee calls each member by name and we respond either “yes/aye” or “no/nay.”

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 16/x We paused considering amendments to switch to voting. This is actually the second vote on each amendment. Right after debate, we take a “voice” vote (everyone who agrees says “yes”). The Chair then rules, normally for the party with more members. In this case, the Democrats.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 15/x Second observation: “Go on mute” is my new phrase for when my kids need to be quiet. I’ve been saying “turn down your volume knob,” but sometimes I really mean “silent!”

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 14/x Chair @RepMaloney again reminds members to “go on mute” because of background noise. Two observations here: (1) this problem isn't limited to virtual hearings. People often discuss amendments among themselves in-person. This can be productive but can also become distracting.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 13/x Will it go 24 hours? Probably not. Some amendments may not be raised. My best guess is 10 hours. This kind of uncertainty is why being a scheduler is the hardest job on the Hill. And note: you can tune in at home (but don’t hold that against me...) https://t.co/SCKIiJNv3V

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 12/x The second factor is how much debate occurs. After the amendment’s author speaks, a member from the other party is recognized for up to 5 minutes, and then it alternates back and forth between members, for 5 minutes each. Then also add openings and votes. See whiteboard ⬇️ https://t.co/rnR0NiUl4k

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 11/x Why does mark-up take hours? The first factor is the number of amendments. The more proposed changes, the longer the process takes. Each person who puts forth an amendment is given 5 minutes to explain their amendment. Today, we expect about 40 amendments.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 10/x Amendments must be "germane," i.e. fall under the committee's jurisdiction to amend the bill. An amendment offered today to expand paid leave for Capitol Police isn't germane. While we have to vote no, I hope my colleagues overseeing the Capitol Police consider this measure.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 9/x Rep. Grothman is making an amendment that would say something the bill already says. Regardless of one’s beliefs, this is just wasting time. It doesn't improve the bill. Our communities have waited and waited for help; now they have to wait through these redundant amendments.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 8/x One GOP mayor wrote to me: "communities like mine are not asking for a 'bail-out.' Local governments do not expect the federal government to make up for every loss of... revenue. Instead, we seek an additional lifeline... to put off and ultimately avoid last resort options."

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 7/x I've heard from nearly every city in my district, all but one of which has a Republican mayor and Republican majority city council, that they strongly support local funding.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 6/x Chair @RepMaloney's opening includes letters from mayors in Republican districts, including Bob Gibbs' and Jim Jordan's, asking for help. Example of non-responsive Congressional speechifying: top Republican says sending resources to state and local governments is “wasteful.”

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
5/x Great question from comments: What is a mark up?

Answer: When a bill is introduced, it's given a number and referred to relevant committees. We'll get feedback from stakeholders. Sometimes we'll have hearings on the bills. Then, we debate and amend (or "mark up") the bill.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
4/x Does wearing glasses help you do good oversight? Maybe. Proud to be part of the club. 🤓

(PS This is my favorite picture of Jim Jordan ever taken.) https://t.co/9WKzcYhaXd

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 3/x That isn’t to say Congress is ready to go full virtual Senate like in Star Wars, although a girl can dream. We just had staff tell a member they weren't on video. “I don’t know what to do. I see a button ‘start my video.’ Do you think I should hit that to start my video?” 🤦‍♀️

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: 2/x The hearing is virtual (we use WebEx). It was to start at 12pmEST, and I logged on 3 entire minutes early, seeking extra credit for good attendance. Virtual hearings save time because we don't have to wait 30 or more minutes for members to physically get to the hearing room.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Today, @OversightDems is "marking up" the COVID relief bill, including state & local funding, paid leave for postal workers, and other issues in our jurisdiction. I’m live tweeting to pull back the curtain for the American people, on how Congress works—and sometimes doesn’t 1/x

name: Rep. Katie Porter

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Due to the pandemic, the support system that previously made full-time work and childcare possible for women has been upended. As a result, millions of women—particularly in corporate America—are leaving or considering leaving the labor force to compensate. (4/10)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: There is no reason to freak out, but we do need to take the shelter-in-place order seriously. If you don't need to, don't leave the house, unless you're going on a hike or a run. Being outside to get some fresh air is totally fine!

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: These jobs are also exempted from shelter in place: healthcare operations, grocery stores, food banks, convenience stores, gas stations and auto repair shops, banks, hardware stores, plumbers, electricians, laundromats, garbage collection. Full list HERE>> https://t.co/gaiJzRjpuY

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Here are some essential tasks: caring for our seniors, minors, dependents, and people with disabilities; caring for a family member in another home; getting supplies like food and medicine; and going to the doctor.

name: Rep. Katie Porter

name: Rep. Katie Porter

And did Big Pharma use the tax cuts they received in the Trump tax law for research and development? Of course not.

These companies have made $73 billion in buybacks from the Trump tax law, far more than some have spent on research and development. (5/6) https://t.co/7VBpFFJKUx

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
From 2006-2015, Big Pharma spent $465 billion on research and development.

In that same time period, drug companies spent $516 billion to buy back their own stock from shareholders. These buybacks mostly enrich the already wealthy—like CEOs. (4/6)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Big Pharma likes to say they “need” money from price hikes to research new cures. This work is important, but it’s not the full story. (3/6)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
My legislation, the Freedom from Price Gouging Act, requires pharmaceutical companies to pay the government back for unnecessary price hikes on drugs covered under Medicare Part B. 

If the price increase is more than inflation, taxpayers shouldn’t foot the bill. (2/6)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: When I was elected, I promised I would fight to drive down the cost of prescription drugs. That’s why I introduced legislation this week taking action against Big Pharma: because we shouldn’t let CEOs line their pockets while older Americans can’t afford their meds. (THREAD)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: A lot of people are asking me to detail what I saw. I’m so glad people are staying engaged in this issue, so took some time to summarize my thoughts in a new thread here: https://t.co/rOpOUrpqF3

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Finally, I learned that I have more to learn. I’ll continue to engage these organizations, try to see more facilities, ask more questions, and push for better solutions. Everyone I encountered at the border deserves nothing less than Congress’ full attention on this. (18/18)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Longer ICE detention and fuller facilities increase the profits of these corporations but may hurt the public. That makes good oversight all the more important. (17/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Fifth, the Otay Mesa Detention Center is run by a for-profit contractor. As a Congressmember, I have a duty to make sure tax dollars are being spent appropriately. Detention should be used to increase public safety, not line the pockets of corporations. (16/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: One detainee I spoke to was a single mom working a good job as an office manager in OC for 10 years. She was paying taxes and caring for her kids. Now that she’s detained, she has two kids who are homeless in OC. And taxpayers are paying to surround her with security. (15/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
Criteria for parole release are inconsistent across ICE detention centers, and judges are not regularly involved in this process.

Fourth, many ICE detentions seem to run counter to public safety and good sense. (14/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Part of the reason for long detentions is that ICE decisions on parole are made by one person at each facility—something that surprised me as this is a hugely impactful decision. (13/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Third, ICE detention is often very long. Some detainees are in prison for over a year, which can cause a backlog of people in Border Patrol custody—and those facilities are not designed to house people for more than a day or two at most. (12/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: As an aside, Border Patrol agents find it challenging to keep kids in custody. They have compassion: one agent took time away from his family on Christmas to dress up as Santa for the kids at that facility. I met a 2-year old and 4-year old with their mom in a cell. (11/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Kids in CBP get screened with 24 hours by agents with EMT training, but these agents are burning out working long shifts with constant medical work. EMT training is not aimed at detecting illness or assessing chronic conditions; it is trauma training. (10/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Second, Border Patrol needs medical personnel and additional medical training. Adults in CBP custody aren’t getting screened by medical professionals at all, and when they get sick, sometimes entire facilities have to be shut down and decontaminated. (9/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: First, better technology will help secure the border. When I asked a border patrol agent if improved technology would help him do his job, he gave a clear yes. And he offered examples and illustrations from his two decades of work. (8/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Below are 6 takeaways I had on how Congress can and should act on to improve the situation at the border: (7/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: The openness and respect from the people on the ground, particularly the career Border Patrol agents, seems inconsistent with the apparent move by DHS leadership to deny congressional staff access to facilities. (6/ ) https://t.co/fSdJmmnOe2

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I’m a big believer in accountability, and ICE employees and CBP officers seemed to support the oversight I was conducting. They spoke candidly with me, asked what else I would like to see, and allowed me to speak directly with detainees. (5/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I personally spoke with immigration advocates, social workers, medical professionals, law enforcement officials, and detainees, including families and children. I am taking what I saw and learned firsthand to my constituents in CA and my colleagues in DC  (4/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: What is happening in CA is different than in TX or AZ. These differences reflect geography, history, culture, resources, and other factors. My first observation to share: the “southern border” is not a monolithic static  thing and our leaders need to see that. (3/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I visited 3 facilities: the non-profit San Diego Rapid Response Network Migrant Shelter, the Otay Mesa ICE Detention Center, and the Chula Vista Border Patrol (CBP) Station. They interact with immigrants at different stages and were very different from each other.  (2/ )

name: Rep. Katie Porter

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: If you agree that mental health should be covered like any other type of healthcare, I hope you’ll join @DonaldNorcross and @RepGusBilirakis in supporting H.R. 3165 and getting this bipartisan bill across the finish line.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text:
H.R. 3165 has 3 main parts:
✅ plans & insurers must conduct in-depth reviews for compliance with law
✅ gov’t officials directed to request these reviews if there are patient complaints
✅ 50 plans & insurers selected at random for annual compliance investigation

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: However, more than a decade later, we’re seeing that health plans and insurers are still violating the law with plans that do not provide equal coverage for mental and medical care. That’s not right, so I introduced a bill to improve enforcement of the existing law.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: It used to be that health plans and insurers could restrict coverage for mental health more than other medical care, so Congress passed the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act in 2008 to right this wrong.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Yesterday, I introduced H.R. 3165, the Mental Health Parity Compliance Act, a bipartisan bill to enforce requirements that health plans and insurers treat mental health services the same as any other type of medical care. (THREAD)

tweet_text: I'm not allowed to promote bone marrow drives. Meanwhile, it's fine for politicians to spend hours and hours a week soliciting corporate PAC money. And it's fine for a politician to leave office and become a lobbyist for the industry they once oversaw. (7/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I'm telling you this because I want the American people to know how backwards our Congressional rules can be. (6/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: It violates House Ethics rules for House members to promote private events, even for non-profits, and even to save the lives of our constituents. So I won't be promoting this event using my official House accounts or resources (because I can't). (5/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I called the House Ethics Committee to see if my office would be able to promote the bone marrow drives being organized across the country for this purpose. Their answer: nope. (4/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: Her community is organizing bone marrow registration drives to help find a match for her, and for other people of South Asian descent, who are under-represented in bone marrow registries. (3/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: One of my constituents came to me recently - she has cancer, and needs a bone marrow donor - quick! (2/8)

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: I'm a new Member of Congress, and sometimes the rules of this place are truly confounding to me. I want to tell you a quick story. (1/8)

tweet_text: It’s time to close the #CharlestonLoophole. That’s why I’m supporting a commonsense bill sponsored by @WhipClyburn that will extend the waiting period for firearm purchases to 10 days, to ensure that guns don’t end up in the wrong hands.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: In 2016, the Charleston loophole meant that 4,170 guns were sold to people with criminal records, mental illnesses, or other circumstances which should have prevented them from being able to buy a gun—because FBI background checks weren’t completed in a three day window.

name: Rep. Katie Porter
tweet_text: In 2015, the Charleston loophole in our gun safety laws allowed a self-proclaimed white supremacist to buy a gun that he then used to kill 9 black parishioners at a Bible study—despite a record of illegal drug possession that should have disqualified his purchase.
